Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the analysis of the sample.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ANALYSIS PHASE: The phase of the sample during this analysis step, needed whenthe phase during the analysis step may not be the same phase as the sample isstored in. For example, a liquid sample may be heated to gaseous form during thestep.
Column Comment.5: ANALYSIS DATE: Date the analysis of the sample began.
Column Comment.6: COMPLETE DATE: The date that this preparation step was completed.
Column Comment.7: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.8: END DATE: The date on which this step ended.
Column Comment.9: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.10: FINAL VOLUME: The final volume of the sample after the completion of anypreparation, processing and analysis to the sample.
Column Comment.12: FINAL VOLUME PERCENT: The percentage of volume remaining of the sample fromthe initial sample after the completion of any preparation, processing and analysis tothe sample.
Column Comment.13: FINAL WEIGHT: The final weight of the sample after the completion of anypreparation, processing and analysis to the sample.
Column Comment.15: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.16: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.17: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.18: PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is a problem withthe step. If a yes flag is indicated, additional information regarding the problemshould be noted in the table ANL_PROBLEM.
Column Comment.19: RECEIVED DATE: Date the sample was received by the laboratory for analysis.
Column Comment.20: RECOVERED PERCENT: the percent by weight of the sample that is recoveredwhen this step is complete.
Column Comment.21: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.22: REPORTED DATE: Date the water sample analysis was reported by the laboratory.
Column Comment.23: RESULTS RECEIVED DATE: The date on which the results from this analysis stepwere received.
Column Comment.24: RESULTS RECEIVED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that the results for thisanalysis step have been received.
Column Comment.25: SAMPLE FRACTION TYPE: The type of fraction method used to separate thesample into two or more samples during this step. This process could involve phaseor chemical separation. A homogeneous separation is possible in cases where thesample is to be subject to different kinds of analysis.
Column Comment.26: SAMPLE QUALITY: The quality of the sample at the completion of this step in thepreparation process.
Column Comment.27: SAMPLE QUALITY DESCRIPTION: Narrative description of the quality of the sampleobserved at a particular stage of an analysis process.
Column Comment.28: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.29: START DATE: the date that this preparation step was started.
Column Comment.30: STEP COMPLETED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not the step hasbeen completed.
Column Comment.31: STEP DESCRIPTION: narrative text description of the processing done during thisstep of preparation. Note that much descriptive information may be structured in thisor associated tables.
Column Comment.32: STEP QUALITY DESCRIPTION: Use this column to note the quality of the step.Details about the problems can be stored in the table ANL_PROBLEM.
Column Comment.33: STEP QUALITY TYPE: The type of quality description given to the step, for example,excellent, good, fair, poor, etc.
Column Comment.34: STEP REQUESTED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not this step isrequested in the work order.
Column Comment.35: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.36: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.37: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.38: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.39: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.40: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.41: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
